content.content: Me: What is their role?

Facilyn: These people are no less important than the decision makers. In fact, they are often vitally important to your whole even though they do not make management decisions within it. You wouldn't be in business without the clients or customers who buy your products, for instance.
Me: What do you mean exactly?

Facilyn: Think about it this way ‚Äî instead of saying that better communication is needed to improve a relationship, describe what a good relationship looks like: "We work as a team that communicates effectively, remains calm under pressure and has fun together."
Facilyn: You're painting a picture of the relationship qualities that will emerge when people treat each other with respect and care.

A harbour-bot and a lighthouse-bot linger at a lonely buoy, trading sea-glass and jokes after a long night guiding ships ‚Äî until the buoy starts giggling and confesses it‚Äôs actually a tiny submarine-bot that parked there for the company.

13_qol_intro.qol_explanation.title: Wait,
13_qol_intro.qol_explanation.subtitle: can you explain a little further?

content.content: Me: Wait, can you explain a little further?

Facilyn: Of course. Your Quality of Life Statement should express why you're doing what you're doing, what you are about, and what you want to become. It's a reflection of what motivates and excites you.

Facilyn: We'll explore four key areas: Economic Well-Being, Relationships, Challenge and Growth, and Purpose and Contribution. Each area helps you articulate different aspects of how you want your life to be.
Outside the window, a dockside robot repeatedly polishes the same already-gleaming bollard, waiting for further instructions‚Äîor meaning, whichever comes first.

13_qol_intro.title: Quality of Life
13_qol_intro.subtitle: How You Want Your Life to Be

content.content: Facilyn takes a long sip of her tea.
Facilyn: Now we come to the heart of it all ‚Äî your Quality of Life Statement. This is no longer about what you already have, but how you want your life to be.
Facilyn: Think of it as your collective sense of what you most value.
Facilyn: We will start with economic well-being.
Me: Agriculture

12_statement_of_purpose.stmp_explanation.title: I am not sure what a Statement of Purpose is.

content.content: Me: I am not sure what a Statement of Purpose is.
Facilyn: A Statement of Purpose captures the positive change your organisation creates. It's the "why" behind everything you do.
Facilyn: For example, a hospital's purpose isn't "To make money from sick people" ‚Äî instead, it can be described like this: "To heal and restore health."
Facilyn: A factory's purpose isn't just "To make things" ‚Äî it might be "To create tools that improve people's lives" or "To transform raw materials into useful products."
Facilyn: Which purpose fits your organisation best?
Out in the harbour, a cargo drone hovers above the docks, job done, purpose pending.

Manage Complexity
Get a taste of how our world is managed into crisis ‚Äî and learn a framework to prevent it.
Me: Why do we define the "whole"?
Facilyn: We‚Äôre trained to think in parts. Departments. Sectors. Issues.
Facilyn: But living systems don‚Äôt function that way.
She glances toward the steaming tea.
Facilyn: Oxygen alone isn‚Äôt water. Hydrogen alone isn‚Äôt water.

content: Facilyn: Studying them separately tells you almost nothing about what water

content.content: is
Facilyn: When you define your whole, you start to see two things: What actually influences it ‚Äî and how your choices ripple outward in return.
Her finger moves outward beyond the circle.
Facilyn: Most management fails because we never define the whole. We manage fragments and hope they behave.
She taps the page lightly.
Facilyn: This is where we stop hoping.
Me: Yes, please.
Facilyn: Great.
Facilyn places a pen and a sheet of thick paper on the table.
Facilyn: Whenever we try to ‚Äúfix‚Äù something, we usually jump straight to the problem.
She smiles gently.
Facilyn: Let‚Äôs not do that.
She draws a slow circle on the paper.
Facilyn: We'll start with something simpler.
She writes three words in the circle, leaving room between them:
Paper: People
Paper: Resources
Paper: Money
Facilyn: A manageable whole has these three essential elements.
She taps the pen next to the first word.
Facilyn: The people who make decisions.
Her hand shifts.
Facilyn: The resources available to you.
Then the last.
Facilyn: And the money you have ‚Äî or can generate.
Facilyn: So before we talk about changing anything...
She nudges the pen a little closer to you.
Facilyn: We define the whole you‚Äôre actually managing.

Frequently asked questions

What is the Whole Under Management?

The Whole Under Management is the ‚Äúunit‚Äù you are managing and making decisions for. It is defined by three things:
‚Ä¢ Decision makers
‚Ä¢ Resource base
‚Ä¢ Money
<details>
<summary>Who counts as a decision maker?</summary>
Anyone who makes day-to-day decisions, carries them out, or has veto power over them. Being inclusive prevents hidden constraints later.
</details>
<details>
<summary>What is the resource base?</summary>

Everything you rely on to support your quality of life and plans. It includes physical resources (land, buildings, equipment) and human resources (people, partners, customers, neighbours, communities).
</details>
<details>
<summary>What is a Holistic Context?</summary>
Your Holistic Context is your shared ‚Äúnorth star‚Äù for decision-making. It describes:
‚Ä¢ The quality of life you want
‚Ä¢ The future resource base needed to sustain it
</details>
<details>
<summary>What else is included in a Holistic Context for organisations?</summary>
For organisations, the Holistic Context also includes a statement of purpose for the organisation.
</details>
<details>
<summary>What are the Filter Questions?</summary>
They are the seven context checks that help you test any action against your holistic context, so you avoid solutions that look good today but create problems tomorrow.
The seven checks are:
‚Ä¢ Cause and Effect
‚Ä¢ Weak Link (social, biological, financial)
‚Ä¢ Marginal Reaction
‚Ä¢ Gross Profit Analysis
‚Ä¢ Energy/Money Source and Use
‚Ä¢ Sustainability
‚Ä¢ Gut Feel
</details>
<details>
<summary>What if an action fails a check?</summary>

It does not automatically mean ‚Äúnever do it‚Äù. It means you have learned where the risk is. You can modify the action, choose a different action, or proceed knowing what you must monitor and control.
</details>
<details>
<summary>Why is Gut Feel last?</summary>
Because it uses the picture you built from the other checks. It asks how you feel about the action in terms of your values, relationships, and consequences for others.
</details>
Me: Why involve everyone?
Facilyn: Leaving out affected parties risks conflict and makes the holistic context meaningless to those excluded.
A faint mechanical whirring passes outside.
Both of you glance toward the window.
A postal robot is attempting to deliver mail to a fire hydrant. It adjusts its angle. Retries. Waits politely, convinced the hydrant is a very quiet resident.
Facilyn watches it for a moment.
Facilyn: See?
Facilyn: The system thinks it has the right address. The hydrant disagrees.
She looks back at you.
Facilyn: Exclude a real stakeholder, and you end up negotiating with a fire hydrant.
Frequently asked questions
What is the Whole Under Management?
The Whole Under Management is the ‚Äúunit‚Äù you are managing and making decisions for. It is defined by three things:
‚Ä¢ Decision makers ‚Ä¢ Resource base ‚Ä¢ Money
Who counts as a decision maker?
Anyone who makes day-to-day decisions, carries them out, or has veto power over them. Being inclusive prevents hidden constraints later.
What is the resource base?

Everything you rely on to support your quality of life and plans. It includes physical resources (land, buildings, equipment) and human resources (people, partners, customers, neighbours, communities).
Why does ‚Äúmoney‚Äù matter here?
Because money is a real constraint and a real tool. It can come from savings, income, credit, or other sources available to your whole.
What is a Holistic Context?
Your Holistic Context is your shared ‚Äúnorth star‚Äù for decision-making. It describes:

content: ‚Ä¢ The quality of life you want ‚Ä¢ The future resource base needed to sustain it

content.content: ‚Ä¢ A statement of purpose for the organisation
What are the Filter Questions?
They are the seven context checks that help you test any action against your holistic context, so you avoid solutions that look good today but create problems tomorrow.
The seven checks are:
‚Ä¢ Cause and Effect ‚Ä¢ Weak Link (social, biological, financial) ‚Ä¢ Marginal Reaction ‚Ä¢ Gross Profit Analysis ‚Ä¢ Energy/Money Source and Use ‚Ä¢ Sustainability ‚Ä¢ Gut Feel
What if an action fails a check?

It does not automatically mean ‚Äúnever do it‚Äù. It means you have learned where the risk is. You can modify the action, choose a different action, or proceed knowing what you must monitor and control.
Why is Gut Feel last?
Because it uses the picture you built from the other checks. It asks how you feel about the action in terms of your values, relationships, and consequences for others.
What are the ‚Äúfilter questions results‚Äù?
They are a summary of your answers across the seven checks, to help you reflect on your decision and revisit anything you skipped.
You walk over to the tank. Faded posters hang from it, half covered in dust.
You can still make out the headlines:
Headline1: Harvests in the region down 70%.
Headline2: Blackouts hit the outskirts.
Headline3: The polycrisis is gaining momentum.

25_fq_marginal_reaction.fqmr_explanation.title: I need help understanding this check

content.content: Me: I need help understanding this check.

Facilyn: Think of it as asking "What's the biggest bang for your buck?" Compare not just the total benefits, but the benefits relative to what you're investing. A small action with modest benefits might have better returns than a large action with bigger benefits if it requires much less investment.
Facilyn: Consider time, money, energy, and opportunity costs - what else could you do with those same resources?
A cargo robot pauses beside a stack of containers, apparently reassessing the cost-benefit of lifting anything ever again.
Me: Why identify rhysical resources?

Facilyn: Physical resources form the foundation of your operations. They represent your capacity to deliver services, produce goods, or create value. Understanding, what physical assets are available, helps you make better management decisions about how to use them effectively.
Facilyn: You may later decide to sell some of the assets you own, so you only need a general reminder of it.
A logistics robot rolls by, diligently cataloguing every object in sight ‚Äî including a confused pigeon, now officially classified as "city‚Äôs air mail transport (unpaid intern)".
Me: What are the ecosystem processes?
Facilyn: With that I mean four major processes we can recognize in our environment.
Water Cycle

content: : How effectively the land catches and holds rain.

content.content: Mineral Cycle

content: : How well nutrients circulate through soil and plants.

content.content: Community Dynamics

content: : How diverse and resilient the community of life is.

content.content: Energy Flow

content: : How much sunlight is captured and turned into life.

content.content: Facilyn: You don't need to be a scientist. Just express your need for surroundings that are stable, productive, and healthy ‚Äî with covered soils, clean water, and thriving biodiversity. Describe them not as they are now, but as they must be to sustain the quality of life that you want for generations.
A gardening robot tends to the plants outside the teahouse, carefully measuring soil moisture and adjusting its watering pattern with the precision of a master horticulturist.

23_fq_cause_effect.fqce_explanation.title: I need help distinguishing cause from symptom

content.content: Me: I need help distinguishing cause from symptom.

Facilyn: Think of it this way ‚Äî symptoms are what you observe or experience, while causes are what creates those symptoms. For example, if robots keep malfunctioning, the symptom is broken robots, but the cause might be poor maintenance or inadequate training.
Facilyn: After finding a cause, you might need to ask yourself multiple times: "Well, and what is the cause of that?" to really get to the root of the problem.
A repair robot wheels past the teahouse, methodically fixing a street lamp that keeps flickering, apparently unaware that the real problem is the faulty electrical connection three blocks away.

4_teahouse.what_up_to.title: Ask what she has been up to

content.content: Me: So. What have you been up to?
Facilyn wraps the string of her teabag once around her finger, thinking.
Facilyn: I‚Äôve been traveling a lot since we last saw each other. Different cities. Different cultures. Same pattern.
She looks down into her cup.
Facilyn: People trying. Really trying. Long meetings. Careful drafts. Building tools they hope will hold.
She looks back up.
Facilyn: And still... the problems multiply faster than the solutions.
Facilyn: The polycrisis isn‚Äôt a streak of bad luck. It‚Äôs not a few broken systems.
Her voice softens slightly.
Facilyn: It‚Äôs the result of how we‚Äôve been managing things for centuries.

onArrival.$code:
Q['decision-makers'] = "Me and people I live or decide with";
Q['part-of'] = "group";

content.content: Me: Let's include the people I live or decide with, and anyone with veto power.
Facilyn: Great. We will treat all of you together as the decision makers in your whole under management.
Me: Sorry, what exactly is a polycrisis?
The vendor raises his eyebrows and gestures towards the harbour with his chin.
Vendor: It used to be simple: first you had a power outtage, then maybe some protests. One after the other.
He counts them off on his fingers.
Vendor: Now the fields burn while the water is scarce, while prices shoot up, while people flee. And each of these things makes the others worse.
He shrugs.
Vendor: That's what they call a polycrisis. Many crises at once, feeding each other.

Facilyn clears a small space on the wooden table. Moves the cups aside.
Facilyn: You manage it by refusing to lose sight of the whole you‚Äôre affecting.
Facilyn: And by filtering every significant decision against a context large enough to hold that whole.
Her hand remains resting on the cleared space between you.
Facilyn: The framework we created helps you do that.
Facilyn: If you want, I‚Äôll walk you through it.
You enter the teahouse.
The noise of wind folds away as the door closes behind you.
Inside, the light is amber and low. Steam rises in slow spirals from clay pots. Cups click softly against saucers.
A thin thread of citrus and jasmine hangs in the air.
At a table near the window, a hand lifts in greeting.
It‚Äôs Facilyn.

She looks at you and smiles.
